Advanced Use Case: SEM Simulation

Here’s a full simulation of an electrostatic lens-only scanning electron microscope (SEM), where we combine electrostatic lenses, einzel lenses, and complex acceleration, focusing and defocusing behaviors in one instance:

 9 import numpy as np
10 from picht import IonOpticsSystem, ElectrodeConfig
11 import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
12
13 system = IonOpticsSystem(nr=100, nz=600, axial_size=0.6, radial_size = 0.1)
14
15
16 wehnelt1 = ElectrodeConfig(
17     start=0,
18     width=30,
19     ap_start=30,
20     ap_width=40,
21     outer_diameter = 50,
22     voltage=-5100
23 )
24 wehnelt2 = ElectrodeConfig(
25     start=30,
26     width=5,
27     ap_start=40,
28     ap_width=20,
29     outer_diameter = 50,
30     voltage=-5100
31 )
32 system.add_electrode(wehnelt1)
33 system.add_electrode(wehnelt2)
34 anode = ElectrodeConfig(
35     start=40,
36     width = 2,
37     ap_start=48,
38     ap_width=4,
39     outer_diameter = 50,
40     voltage=0
41 )
42 cathode = ElectrodeConfig(
43     start=22,
44     width = 2,
45     ap_start=50,
46     ap_width=0,
47     outer_diameter = 2,
48     voltage=-5000
49 )
50
51 system.add_electrode(anode)
52 system.add_einzel_lens(
53     position=80.0,
54     width=60.0,
55     aperture_center=50.0,
56     aperture_width=48.0,
57     outer_diameter=50.0,
58     focus_voltage=-7000
59 )
60
61 system.add_einzel_lens(
62     position=160.0,
63     width=60.0,
64     aperture_center=50.0,
65     aperture_width=48.0,
66     outer_diameter=50.0,
67     focus_voltage=-6500
68 )
69 potential = system.solve_fields()
70
71 trajectories = system.simulate_beam(
72     energy_eV= 10,
73     start_z=0.025,
74     r_range=(0.0499925, 0.0500075),
75     angle_range=(-2, 2),
76     num_particles=6,
77     simulation_time=1e-8
78 )
79
80 figure = system.visualize_system(
81     trajectories=trajectories)
82
83 plt.show()

Total running time of the script: (0 minutes 25.762 seconds)
